Chapter 2.36

Early May 1435, Midday

The bells of Rome ring in celebration as you ride alongside Pope Eugenius IV through the streets leading toward the Vatican. The May sun warms the stone facades, and the people who days ago might have hurled stones now press forward to catch a glimpse of the returned pontiff. Florentine lancers in their red-and-gold livery form a cordon ahead, while behind you ride the sixty-seven Vatican Guards who chose Florence over desertion—men seeking to reclaim their honor through service.

Tommaso Parentucelli rides a few paces back, his saddlebags heavy with the reform documents preserved through the flight. Fray Hernando is there too, his face drawn from the weeks of exile but his eyes bright with gratitude. Your own Caballeros del Defensor maintain their disciplined formation, Rodrigo de Mendoza at their head, the white banner with its golden cross catching the breeze.

Eugenius leans toward you, his voice low beneath the cheering. The papal tiara sits heavy on his brow, but his eyes hold a warmth that transcends formality. He has already agreed to the Swiss Guard, confirmed Alfonso's Naples investiture, and promised support against the Ottomans.

"What else, old friend?" the Pope asks again, his tone almost conspiratorial. "You have restored my city, gathered evidence that may yet expose the rot in my own household, and asked for nothing but what serves Christendom. Surely there is something you desire for yourself? For Castile? I am not so old that I cannot recognize when a man restrains his tongue."

The procession slows as you approach the steps of St. Peter's, where Cardinal-deacons wait with holy water and incense. You have perhaps a minute before ceremony demands your attention.

What Has Happened at Basel (Late 1434 - Early 1435):

Cardinal Cesarini has successfully argued that reform matters more than constitutional theory. His relentless message—"We came here to heal the Church, not to wage war on the Pope"—has worn down all but the most committed radicals.

The Council passed a carefully worded resolution in January 1435 praising "the cooperation of Pope and Council in the work of reform" without addressing the supremacy question. The phrase was Cesarini's masterstroke: it implies neither submission nor victory, merely partnership in a holy cause.

Cardinal d'Allemand's faction has shrunk to perhaps 40 committed supporters—enough to obstruct but not enough to command. Many French delegates went home after the Compacts of Basel ended the Hussite Wars, satisfied that the Council had accomplished something historic. The Germans, never enthusiastic about French-led radicalism, have largely drifted toward the moderate center.

Cardinal Rochetaillée's conversion (Roll 99 in Chapter 2.21) proved significant. His public acknowledgment that "my cause had become about power rather than reform" gave cover to others who wanted to step back from the brink. Several bishops followed his lead.

The Greek union negotiations are proceeding—envoys arrived in September 1434 to discuss where the reunion council should be held. This remains undecided (Basel wants it in Basel or Avignon; the Greeks want somewhere in Italy accessible by sea), but the discussions are in good faith. The Pope is involved through his legates.

Session 20 (January 22, 1435) passed decrees against clerical concubinage and abuses of excommunication—reforms the Pope had already endorsed through parallel legislation. Session 21 is being prepared for June, likely addressing benefice reservations.

The worst has been avoided—for now. The constitutional question remains a sleeping dragon. If Eugenius stumbles badly, d'Allemand could revive it. But the momentum favors continued cooperation.

"You think like a cardinal, not a king," Eugenius murmurs, keeping his voice beneath the crowd's cheering. "Yes. Italy has many such. Spain too, I think. If Castile sent another dozen delegates... theologians, canonists, men of learning who would be welcomed by Cesarini..."

Basel wants Avignon or Basel itself. The Greeks refuse anywhere they cannot reach by ship. Constantinople, perhaps, or somewhere in Italy."

He glances at you. "The location question may be the rock on which d'Allemand's ambitions finally break. The Greeks will not come to him, and he cannot force them."

A cardinal-deacon approaches with holy water. Eugenius lowers his voice to barely a breath.

"You also left petitions with Us before Constantinople. The Dominican endowment. The Inquisition mandate for Granada. The Military Orders charter. We have not forgotten. Come to Us tomorrow, privately, and We shall address them all."

Santa Maria sopra Minerva
Early Afternoon, May 1435

The Dominican motherhouse rises above the ruins of an ancient temple to Minerva—Roman wisdom repurposed for Christian truth. The church's plain brick facade belies the grandeur within: soaring Gothic vaults, chapels adorned by the finest artists of Italy, and the tombs of two popes.

The porter, a young friar with ink-stained fingers, goes pale when he recognizes the arms on your surcoat. Within minutes, you are escorted through the cloister to the Master General's study.

Fra Bartholomew Texier, Master General of the Order of Preachers, rises from behind a desk buried in correspondence. He is perhaps sixty, French by birth, with the lean features of a man who has never stopped fasting even after achieving high office. His eyes are sharp, assessing—the eyes of a man who has governed an order of thousands across all Christendom for nearly a decade.

"Your Majesty." He bows precisely—respect without servility. "You honor our house. I had heard you were in Constantinople, defending the faith against the Turk. And yet here you stand in Rome, having restored the Holy Father to his city."

He gestures to a chair. Wine and water appear without being summoned.

"I confess curiosity. Kings do not often visit the Master General of the Dominicans without purpose. How may the Order of Preachers serve the Crown of Castile?"

Fra Bartholomew listens without interruption, his fingers steepled beneath his chin. When you finish, he remains silent for a long moment—the silence of a man who has heard many kings speak of God's purposes and learned to distinguish genuine piety from gilded ambition.

"The kingdom of heaven," he repeats softly. "You speak like a friar, Your Majesty. Or perhaps like a crusader who has seen too much of the world's darkness and yearns for light."

He rises and moves to the window, looking out over the cloister where Dominican novices walk in quiet contemplation.

"What you describe—priests for the poor, hospitals, food for the hungry, preaching to strengthen families in faith—this is the very mission Saint Dominic founded our Order to fulfill. We are the Ordo Praedicatorum. We exist to preach, to teach, to bring souls to God." He turns back to you. "So yes, Your Majesty, what you ask aligns with our purpose."

"But."

The word hangs in the air.

"Kings who speak of God's kingdom often mean their own kingdom dressed in vestments. I do not say this is true of you—I say only that I must ask questions a Master General must ask."

He returns to his chair, leaning forward.

"First: What independence would my friars have? A Dominican answers to his prior, his provincial, and ultimately to me and to the Holy Father. Not to kings. We preach truth as the Church defines it, even when that truth is inconvenient to thrones. Can you accept friars in your kingdom who may one day tell you that you have sinned?"

His eyes hold yours.

"Second: You speak of Granada. The Inquisition mandate you have petitioned for—I know of it. The Dominicans have long served as inquisitors. But inquisition is a blade that cuts carefully or not at all. What do you envision for the converts of Granada? Instruction in faith? Or interrogation of doubt?"

"Third: Funding. Hospitals, food programs, priests for poor parishes—these require gold, and gold given creates obligation. What do you offer, and what do you expect in return?"

He spreads his hands.

"Speak plainly, Your Majesty. I am too old for courtly dancing. If your vision is truly holy, plainness will only make it shine brighter."

Fra Bartholomew's expression shifts subtly—the guarded assessment giving way to something approaching genuine interest. He picks up a quill, turns it absently in his fingers, then sets it down.

"You answer well, Your Majesty. Better than most who sit in that chair."

He rises and pours two cups of wine, handing one to you directly rather than letting a servant do it—a gesture of respect between equals in conversation, if not in rank.

"The independence of the Order is not negotiable, and you have not tried to negotiate it. That alone distinguishes you from... others." A flicker of something—old frustrations with other monarchs, perhaps—crosses his face. "And your framing of the Inquisition mandate is sound. The purpose is not persecution but discernment. To protect the sincere from being tarred by the false. To give genuine converts the honor they deserve for their sacrifice, while ensuring the sacraments are not profaned by those who mouth words they do not believe."

He returns to his seat, cradling the wine.

"As for the gold being a gift—" A thin smile. "I have been Master General for nine years. I have learned that gifts from kings always carry weight, even when no conditions are spoken. But the weight you describe—a stronger kingdom, more souls in grace, more voices raised in praise—that is weight the Order of Preachers was built to carry."

He drinks, considers.

"Tell me of the practicalities, Your Majesty. You speak of priests for parishes that cannot fund them. How many parishes? Granada alone, or Castile entire? The hospitals and food programs—administered by whom? Dominican brothers, or secular authorities with Dominican chaplains?"

He leans back. "And the endowment you have petitioned His Holiness for—I know of it, though I do not know the sum. What scale of commitment does Castile envision? A dozen friars? A hundred? A new province of the Order?"

His eyes sharpen with practical calculation now, the theologian giving way to the administrator.

"I ask not to diminish your vision, but to understand it. The Order has some eight thousand friars across Christendom. We are stretched thin in places, abundant in others. If Castile calls, I must know what voice to answer with."

Fra Bartholomew sets down his wine and pulls a piece of parchment toward him, reaching for his quill with the practiced motion of a man who thinks best with ink flowing.

"A fair question. Let me think aloud."

He scratches figures as he speaks.

"A Dominican friar costs perhaps fifteen to twenty florins per year to maintain—food, habit, books, travel. We live simply. But maintaining a friar is not the same as creating one. Formation takes seven years: novitiate, philosophy, theology, practical training. You cannot buy friars like you buy horses."

He looks up. "So the question becomes: what can gold accomplish now, and what can it build for the future?"

He draws a line, dividing the parchment.

"A modest gift—five thousand florins."

"This sustains what exists. It funds perhaps ten itinerant preachers for five years, traveling the rural areas of Castile where parishes cannot support a resident priest. They arrive, they preach, they hear confessions, they baptize, they move on. Better than nothing. But they do not stay."

"A substantial gift—twenty-five thousand florins."

"Now we can build. One new Dominican house in an underserved region—perhaps Granada, perhaps the northern mountains. A community of twelve to fifteen friars with a church, a modest hospital attached, a school for children. This becomes permanent. The house sustains itself through small endowments and alms once established. The friars preach in surrounding villages, train local men who show vocation, grow over generations."

He taps the quill. "Twenty-five thousand also funds a studium—a house of studies where we train Castilian novices rather than sending them abroad. This multiplies our numbers over time. Ten novices this year become ten friars in seven years, who train ten more..."

"A princely gift—fifty thousand florins or more."

"This transforms the Dominican presence in Castile entirely. Three new houses: one in Granada for the converted, one in the rural north, one perhaps in Extremadura or wherever need is greatest. A hospital network attached to each. A central studium generale rivaling Salamanca for Dominican formation. Funds for books, for copying manuscripts, for building libraries that preserve learning."

He pauses. "And—importantly—funds to recruit. Not just Castilians, but friars from other provinces who might transfer to serve in your kingdom. Italians, Germans, Frenchmen who speak some Castilian or would learn. This accelerates everything by a decade."

"A perpetual endowment—land or rents generating annual income."

Fra Bartholomew sets down the quill and meets your eyes.

"This is different in kind, not just degree. A perpetual endowment means the work continues after you die. After I die. It becomes part of what the Order is in Castile, not merely what it does for a season. The hospitals never close for lack of funds. The preachers never stop walking. The schools never turn away a bright child because there is no money for ink."

He spreads his hands. "But perpetual endowments require papal approval, legal frameworks, protections against future kings who may not share your vision. They are... complicated."
